G.L. c. 84, \u00a7\u00a7 15-18.proposition: Defendant is responsible for maintaining the sidewalk abutting the Property in a safe and reasonably hazard-free condition pursuant to Massachusetts law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 84, §§ 15-18 and the duty of care established by common law precedents.

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to all individuals lawfully present on the sidewalk abutting the Property to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition pursuant to statute and common law.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The court expressly states that a property owner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition, and it abolishes any special limitation for snow and ice. While the facts involve a parking lot rather than a public sidewalk, the opinion broadly reaffirms the general premises-liability duty under both common law and in light of existing regulations requiring means of access and egress (which include walkways) to be kept free of snow and ice. Thus, it supports the general proposition that a defendant owes a duty of reasonable care to lawful persons on abutting walking areas to maintain the premises safely.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to “act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.” … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.

*Schirripa v. Western Realty, Inc.*, 321.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that landlords, property owners, and individuals with control over premises abutting sidewalks are obligated to address foreseeable dangers posed to lawful pedestrians.
*Schirripa v. Western Realty, Inc.*, 321.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the effect of selling the good will of a restaurant and whether the seller may open a competing business nearby. It does not address premises liability, sidewalk conditions, duties owed to pedestrians, or any obligations of landlords or abutters to address foreseeable dangers on sidewalks. Therefore it does not support the stated proposition about Massachusetts law on sidewalk-related duties of landowners or those in control of abutting premises.
*Schirripa v. Western Realty, Inc.*, 321.relevant_excerpt: “The only question argued relates to the obligation imposed upon the defendants by their voluntary transfer of the good will of the restaurant and liquor business. … It is settled in this Commonwealth that when a man voluntarily sells the good will of his business he thereby precludes himself from setting up a competing business which will derogate from the good will which he has sold.”

*Souza v. Southworth*, 564 F.2d 609 (1st.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that landlords, property owners, and individuals with control over premises abutting sidewalks are obligated to address foreseeable dangers posed to lawful pedestrians.
*Souza v. Southworth*, 564 F.2d 609 (1st.support_reasoning: The opinion in Souza v. Southworth concerns attorneys’ fees in civil rights litigation and the standards for setting reasonable fee awards under 42 U.S.C. § 1988. It does not discuss Massachusetts tort law, premises liability, sidewalks, or any duty owed by landlords or property owners to pedestrians. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about obligations of those controlling premises abutting sidewalks.
*Souza v. Southworth*, 564 F.2d 609 (1st.relevant_excerpt: As we said in King, the assessment of a reasonable fee in a particular case rests within the sound discretion of the district court. 560 F.2d at 1026, citing Johnson v. Georgia Highway Express, Inc., 488 F.2d 714, 717 (5th Cir. 1974). This means that we will look for a reasoned discussion of those factors that the court finds relevant.

*Barry v. Beverly Enters.-Mass., Inc.*,.proposition: Defendant had actual notice of the icy condition based on tenant warnings and photographs and had an opportunity to remedy the hazard but failed to act.
*Barry v. Beverly Enters.-Mass., Inc.*,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely rejects the idea that the defendant had actual (or constructive) notice of the icy condition. The court holds that there was insufficient evidence to infer the defendant knew or should have known of the ice, expressly finding the cook’s comment about it being “always a mess back there” too vague to establish notice. Thus, the case is authority against, not in favor of, the proposition that defendant had actual notice and an opportunity to remedy the hazard but failed to act.
*Barry v. Beverly Enters.-Mass., Inc.*,.relevant_excerpt: “After reviewing the evidence presented at the first trial, we conclude that the defendant’s motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict should have been allowed… Specifically, we hold that the evidence did not warrant an inference that the defendant knew, or in the exercise of reasonable care should have known, of the icy condition that caused the plaintiff’s fall… Contrary to the plaintiff’s suggestion, the cook’s statement… does not provide support for an inference that the defendant violated its duty to the plaintiff.”

*Delano v. Garrettson-Ellis Lumber Co.*,.proposition: Defendant knew or should have known that melted and refrozen snow would create ice and pose a danger to lawful pedestrians.
*Delano v. Garrettson-Ellis Lumber Co.*,.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with negligent snow and ice clearance and whether an artificial accumulation was allowed to persist, but it does not squarely address the specific foreseeability concept that melted and refrozen snow would create ice dangerous to pedestrians. The evidence referenced involves plowing, sanding, ruts, and powdery snow over ‘muddy ice,’ with melting temperatures on prior days, yet the court does not articulate a rule about the defendant knowing or having reason to know that melt-and-refreeze would pose a danger. Thus, the case is about negligent maintenance of snow/ice rather than the particular proposition stated.
*Delano v. Garrettson-Ellis Lumber Co.*,.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff’s testimony to a condition like ‘muddy ice,’ with ruts three and four inches deep, covered and obscured by a half inch of snow, was reinforced by the meteorologist’s testimony about snowfall consistent with such a condition. The jury could infer that the clearing was negligently done and that the resulting condition was negligently allowed to continue for several days. Lanagan v. Jordan Marsh Co. 324 Mass. 540, 541-542. Willett v. Pilotte, 329 Mass. 610, 613.”

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 708-.proposition: Defendant’s breach of her duty of care directly caused Plaintiff to slip and fall, resulting in physical injury and substantial economic losses.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 708-.support_reasoning: The excerpt is a concurring opinion discussing the proper framework for occupiers’ liability, specifically criticizing the continued use of status categories like trespasser, licensee, and invitee. It does not address causation, slipping and falling, or resulting physical or economic injuries, nor does it make any finding that a defendant’s breach directly caused a plaintiff’s fall and losses. Therefore, this citation does not support the specific proposition about breach, causation, and damages from a slip-and-fall incident.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 708-.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that “trespassers” stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential.
